snippet: A mining surge on the Tibetan plateau has provided valuable resources for China’s economy, but the environmental damage has stirred anger among people living there.
abstract: Rescuers have pulled 54 dead miners from rubble at site of landslide that buried 83 people at mining camp in Gyama Valley, Tibet; disaster, one of China's worst mining accidents, has thrown spotlight on mining operations in region, which are central to Communist Party's plans for growth but decried by Tibetans due to environmental damage.

byline.contributor: Patrick Zuo and Amy Qin contributed research.

lead_paragraph: A mining surge on the Tibetan plateau has provided valuable resources for China’s economy, but the environmental damage has stirred anger among people living there.

headline.seo: Deadly Tibetan Landslide Draws Attention to Mining
headline.main: Fatal Landslide Draws Attention to the Toll of Mining on Tibet
headline.print_headline: Fatal Landslide Draws Attention to the Toll of Mining on Tibet
